text: I'm David Adams and I'm professor of
surgery at the Medical University of
South Carolina and co-director of the
digestive disease center I've been here
for 30 years and my practice has been
taking care of people with complicated
disorders of their abdomen and the
organs that lie inside the abdominal
cavity one of the organs that can be
really pain just a terrible cause of
suffering is the stomach and what I'm
talking about today are patients who
have stomachs that stopped working for a
variety of reasons we call this gastric
paris's and it means paralysis of the
stomach it occurs frequently in patients
who have diabetes and it also occurs for
reasons that we don't understand
sometimes we think there may be some
viral illness that causes a dysfunction
but it shows up in a large number of
women in the middle years of their life
most patients with gastric Parris's can
be managed with a variety of medicines
but there's some patients in whom all
the medicines in the world are given to
and they continue to have debilitating
nausea vomiting and frequently have
weight loss which may require feeding
with feeding tubes or even intravenous
feeding it's possible to correct this
condition when medical treatment fails
with a surgical procedure which involves
putting a pacemaker into the stomach
similar to what you do for a heart that
has a malfunction in its electrical
system Medtronic has developed this
system and what it is it's a small disc
shape generator it has a battery in it
that gets placed underneath the skin and
it's connected by wires into the stomach
there are two leads that get placed into
the wall of the stomach and they
stimulate the electrical system of the
stomach with an intermittent pulse of
electricity in many patients this is
miraculous they may wake up from surgery
in nausea which is
and present for years is suddenly gone
they are able to eat they were able to
get off of feeding tubes intravenous
feeding it can really be life-changing
for many patients in particular young
diabetics seem to do very well with this
procedure because the electrical signal
seems to interrupt the signals that give
them nausea so that a young diabetic
patient who spends his days and weeks in
and out of the emergency room for poo
poor blood sugar control for dehydration
suddenly is able to take a diet where
they can control their diabetes where
they can nourish themselves by mouth and
avoid the repetitive visits to emergency
rooms and hospitalizations we've been
doing this at MUSC for over five years
that have done over a hundred patients
and it doesn't work in everyone some
patients it's effective immediately
others it may take two to three months
for the electrical architecture of the
stomach to remodel so that they benefit
from it the Pacers are run by a small
battery and for patients who have the
Pacers effective at a low setting the
battery may last for six to eight years
other patients require running the
generator at high settings and the
generators in that case may run out in a
year's time sometimes even less when the
battery runs out of juice it's an
outpatient procedure to replace it
patients come in to the hospital go to
the operating room and in a 30 minute
procedure we remove the generator and
replace it with a new one I think
the placement of a gastric stimulator
can be a life-saving
procedure for many patients who have not
benefited from traditional medical
therapy it definitely can improve the
quality of life and it's a procedure
that has a low complication rate low
risk rate and I'm very pleased that we
can offer it here in South Carolina to
many patients who need it and many
patients who may not be aware that it's
available and that is a possible
solution to what could be years of
nausea vomiting malnutrition and need
for multiple emergency room and hospital
visits
